Hello,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wro=
te:
> Still, there's a flipside to the whole "can't generate a method stub"=
 
> argument. With EasyMock, if I use a faked or mocked method that doesn't=
 
> yet exist, my test can't even compile yet! 

That makes a lot of sense,=
 since Java is typed at compile time.
And every modern IDE generates the me=
thod automatically,
with matching parameter types and return type.

> When =
I practise TDD, I often 
> design interfaces, and forcing me to generate a =
method stub for a method 
> I might not even like yet is annoying. Keeping =
the methods as strings 
> allows me to write the test, compile it, and even=
 run it before I decide 
> whether the interface or method signature is goo=
d enough to start 
> putting into stone.

1) With that method, you never se=
e the method 
    as a real method call as in EasyMock. Compare 

control.e=
xpectAndReturn(mock.copy(destination, source), true);   // EasyMock 1.2

ex=
pect(mock.copy(destination, source)).andReturn(true); // EasyMock 2.0 / 2.1=


to 

mock.expects(once()).method("copy").with( eq(destination), eq(source=
) ).will(returnValue
(true)); // JMock

In the EasyMock examples, both show=
 how the method 
is used copy(destination, source) and returning true.
It i=
s easy to see that the parameters should be reordered,
and with refactoring=
-tools, it's quite fast.

In the JMock example, it is not that easy to spot=
 the method call, because
the method name is in a string, and the parameter=
s are separated from this string.
It is harder to see that the parameters s=
hould be reordered,
and as refactoring tools don't work, it's a pain - espe=
cially if
the method is used more than once already in the tests, you have =
to change
every single ocurrence by hand.

2) Can you explain on how you te=
st-drive a plain old java method then,
without adding a body for it?


-
Ta=
mmo Freese
